visualization_data.title: Window Tax Visualization Assets
visualization_data.description: Visual elements for recreating the Window Tax story

parliament_debate_1696.setting: Palace of Westminster, House of Commons

wealthy_house_blocking.lighting: bright daylight contrasting with dark blocked areas

pitt_triple_assessment.lighting: bright desk lighting, shadows in corners

health_crisis_documentation.lighting: clinical but dim due to blocked windows

final_abolition_1851.lighting: bright, symbolic sunlight streaming through windows

georgian_windows.description: Large sash windows with multiple panes
georgian_windows.details: White painted frames, vertical sliding mechanism, decorative glazing bars

bricked_windows.description: Windows filled with brick and mortar
bricked_windows.details: Different colored brick from main wall, visible mortar lines, sometimes painted over

tenement_buildings.details: Narrow frontages, minimal windows, poor construction, overcrowded

georgian_mansions.details: Classical proportions, stone facades, iron railings, grand entrance doors

clipped_coins.visual_description: Silver coins with irregular edges, reduced weight
clipped_coins.historical_significance: Evidence of the crisis that led to the window tax

tax_receipts.visual_description: Small paper documents with official stamps and signatures
tax_receipts.historical_significance: Proof of individual tax burden and bureaucratic process

window_counting_tools.visual_description: Leather satchels, counting sheets, quills, small telescope
window_counting_tools.historical_significance: Equipment used by 'window peepers' for assessment

protest_graffiti.visual_description: Chalk writing on bricked windows: 'Lighten our darkness we beseech thee, O Pitt!'
protest_graffiti.historical_significance: Public protest against the 1797 rate increases

household_words_magazine.visual_description: Victorian periodical with Dickens' anti-window tax articles
household_words_magazine.historical_significance: Key propaganda tool in the abolition campaign

light_vs_darkness.description: Contrast between well-lit and blocked window areas
light_vs_darkness.usage: To show the literal 'daylight robbery' effect

coins_and_money.description: Clipped coins, tax receipts, money bags
coins_and_money.usage: To show the financial motivations and costs

architectural_scars.usage: To show lasting impact of the tax policy

class_contrast.description: Wealthy Georgian mansions vs poor tenements
class_contrast.usage: To show unequal impact of the tax

health_imagery.description: Sick people, medical instruments, dark rooms
health_imagery.usage: To show health consequences of blocked windows

timeline_visual_markers.1747: First revision - New rate structure charts
timeline_visual_markers.1797: Triple assessment - War imagery and mass protest
timeline_visual_markers.1850: Dickens campaign - Publishing and reform imagery
